data.title: Friday Favourites
data.text:

Iâ€™m off down a musical rabbit hole again ferreting out Friday Favourites.

So it starts with thinking what from my collection would make a good weekend kickoff, up pops Boogie 2nite by Booty Luv.

Now I know that Booty Luv are made up of former Big Brovaz members and so it makes sense to drop in a link to â€˜Nu-flowâ€™ which draws me back to the Saturdayâ€™s earworm from last week but I swerve that tangent.

But then I start digging into the detail.

Turns out the top Booty Luv singles are covers (I know, shocker!).

Boogie 2nite was originally performed by Tweet and â€œDonâ€™t mess with my manâ€ by Lucy Pearl, so I give them both a listen;

And as I listen to the original (above) Mr Earworm takes hold and transports me across to â€˜Donâ€™tâ€™ by Mr Edward Sheeran.

There is somewhat more than just a titular similarity hear, although thatâ€™s not uncommon for the 8th most streamed artist on Spotify. (No Scrubs / Shape of You ?)

So this is rapidly turning into a Midweek post but who cares? Iâ€™m having fun. Party for one anybody? ğŸ™‚

PS the Single mix of Boogie 2nite was the Seamus Haji Big Love Edit (featured above), not the version of audio that appeared in the official video release, which in case youâ€™re interested was the remix by DB Boulevard which you can find here â€“ not quite as â€œpartyâ€ though.

I have a trio of treats for you this Friday following a theme of lyrical advice for all across the ages.

Starting off with Gil Scott Heronâ€™s â€œThe Revolution will Not be Televisedâ€. Funky, Flute-y, Jazzy, wordy, full of attitude, smarts, political and social commentary.

And if you like that, roll up for lovingly crafted, 21st century homage to Mr Heron, courtesy of Smoove, aka Steven Moove, titularly 50% of soul-funksters Smoove and Turrell.

There is just a hint of Geordie twang in Ferank Manseedâ€™s vocals, plenty of updated witty commentary, at least as much flute as the original, and a boat load more funk.

Finishing off this weekâ€™s Friday Favourites is further inciteful scribbling cleverly crafted by Mr Political Poet Scroobius Pip and accompanied by the casio-inspired bleeps and beats of Dan Le Sac

And if you fancy a hard-er-core dance version try this Flat Eric-Phat Beat mash/mix

Club away my party hearty friends, or as Cameo would say, Word Up!

Donovan, out.

OK I lied, couldnâ€™t really go without popping in this bonus. This got played immediately before U2 came out on stage for their mass-multimedia extravaganza, Zoo TV. Fits right in on this post.

Having established some weeks ago my love of fast-talking mcâ€™s, Iâ€™m adding another word-heavy lyrical-waxing to the Friday Favourites list. Whilst not quite in the same speed-league as Andy Cooper & The Allergies â€˜Rock Rockâ€™, this weekâ€™s musical literary madness comes courtesy of Danny Goffeyâ€™s alter-ego Vangoffey.

â€œRace of Lifeâ€ exploded into my world courtesy of a play on Shaun Keavenyâ€™s Radio 6Music Breakfast show one morning. I fell in love with it immediately; cheeky spoken lyrics, evolutionary references abound and a catchy beat â€“ whatâ€™s not to like?

As joyful as Bloodhound Gangâ€™s â€œBad Touchâ€ (which I predict will make another appearance at some point) and a touch smoother to boot, the song offers a gentle reminder that every one of us are incredibly lucky to be alive; it was always far more probable that someone else would have been born in our place than us given the odds (which you can check here!)

It turns out that Danny Goffey has been on the music scene for quite some time, although formerly at the back of the stage, as Supergrassâ€™s drummer. My musical ignorance never fails to amaze and delight me.

And in case you were wondering, the smartly dressed teen seen lip-syncing in the video is Dannyâ€™s youngest son, Frankie.

Thatâ€™s it for now. Tomorrow brings more written delights.

Donovan.

Friday favourites time rolls around again. This slot should be the easiest post of each week, all I have to do is pick a favourite tune and put it here. However without a reason, or a story that provides some justification to go with it thereâ€™s nothing for you to engage with.

If itâ€™s a track you already know youâ€™ll either like it, or not, and itâ€™s probably not going to add anything to your day. If itâ€™s one you donâ€™t know however, then thatâ€™s a different story.

So my endeavours on Friday Favourites will vary depending on how well known I think the song is; if I drop a Fleetwood Mac classic in then you can expect a reasonably comprehensive explanation as to why itâ€™s made the list (rather than assuming anyone elseâ€™s musical tastes). If itâ€™s a track from an artist with limited audience awareness there may be less for me to say but Iâ€™ll be really keen to get feedback on whether youâ€™ve heard it before, and if you like it (or not). A bit of validation is always good for the soul.

As the weeks pass by Iâ€™ll be adding all the Friday Favorites to a Spotify and YouTube Playlist.

This weekâ€™s track is another one of those Spotify â€œDiscover Weeklyâ€™ discoveries. It is proving to be a continual source of genre-linked delights and for me, proves the algorithms they have churning away in the background are getting good at offering up relevant recommendations.

The Torpedo Boyz were not a band Iâ€™d heard of and itâ€™s not that surprising, Wikipedia describes them as a German/Japanese electronic music duo and to my knowledge they have had very little exposure in the U.K. However several artists I regularly listen to like Skeewiff, Smoove and Lack of Afro had remixed their tracks â€“ which would explain the reason â€˜Are you talkinâ€™ to meâ€™ appeared on the recommended list.

It was a straight â€˜like and save to playlistâ€™ without even getting to the end of my first listen. The songâ€™s monologue story delivered with a strange, almost central Americanesque tone combined with music that reminded me of the a couple of the songs from the soundtrack to the Playstation game Little Big Planet made it immediately appealing. It never fails to brighten my spirits and endless replays havenâ€™t dampened the joy that it evokes.

So the answer to the question is yes, I am talking to you, and I hope youâ€™ll be talking to me about these Friday Favourites.

Subscribe to the blog (new form at the bottom of the page), like/follow the facebook page, leave a comment or message, anything really.

Thatâ€™s why weâ€™re here, well why Iâ€™m here anyway ğŸ™‚

Tomorrow or the day after that, Iâ€™ll be here when you get back

Donovan.

Hauntingly beautiful.

Thatâ€™s how I would describe this weekâ€™s Friday Favourite. I came across it, as I expect a large number of people did, when it was used for the theme music to the most excellent â€˜Broenâ€™, or â€˜Bronâ€™, depending on whether your native tongue is Danish or Swedish.

Known in the UK as â€˜The Bridgeâ€™, the four seasons of subtitled serial-killer fayre provide some of the best non-US drama for over a decade. Imagine the darkness of the other Danish police drama â€˜The Killingâ€™, crossed with the likes of â€˜In the line of dutyâ€™ and â€˜The Fallâ€™ and you are probably getting close. The dialogue is faultless and the storylines will keep you guessing long into each series.

As for the theme music (which is broadly why weâ€™re here), well I think it speaks for itself. Listen to it alone, or with the expertly matched and truly gorgeous visuals of the titular Ã˜resund Bridge at the beginning of each episode. Written by Danish musicians Jannis Noya Makrigiannis and Anders Rhedin and recorded by Makrigiannis with a collection of musicians as part of his project â€˜Choir of Young Believersâ€™. Released in Denmark in 2008 and across the rest of Europe in 2009 as part of the album â€˜This is for the whites in your eyesâ€™.

Treat yourself and take a few minutes to kick back and unwind to this enchanting melodic delight.

Donovan
